Project Abstract
CSR: Small: Turbo Button: A Semantically-Smart SSD-based RAID System for 
Internet-Scale Applications
   
   It is timely and opportunistic to rethink the designs of flash-memory SSD-integrated RAID storage systems for Internet-scale applications. Therefore, how to best utilize the high sequential-I/O performance and cost-efficient characteristics of HDD to assist the SSD-based RAID systems becomes an important research issue. This project seeks to develop a Semantically-Smart SSD (S4D) framework to explore and exploit the file system and application semantic information to boost the performance and improve the reliability of flash-memory SSDs. 

In particular, this project qualitatively and quantitatively identifies the critical issues for existing flash-memory SSDs, and conveys the file-system block liveness and correlation information to the underlying S4D with the standard or modified block interface. Secondly, S4D exploits the block liveness information to efficiently supplement the log-block pool with free blocks, and reduce the FTL block mapping table size. Finally, based on S4D, Turbo Button, an SSD-HDD-Hybrid RAID storage system, will be designed and constructed, in order to leverage the advantages of HDD judiciously to address the problems of straightforwardly applying RAID algorithms to SSDs. The broader impact of the project lies in its (1) research development that provides significant performance, reliability, and energy-efficiency improvement for existing and future flash-based and flash-integrated storage systems (specially RAID-structured storage systems) widely deployed in data centers that serve the Internet-scale application community; (2) infrastructure development that enhances research and education at UNL and, through accessibility via public domain, the high performance and data-intensive computing community.

por.por_cntn:
Although there are a large number of performance mechanisms integrated into flash-memory SSDs, they generally fall far short of their performance potentials due to the lack of the exploration and exploitation of file-system and application semantic knowledge beneath the block interface. The key accomplishment of this project is the development of a framework, called Semantically-Smart SSD-based RAID System (Turbo Button), to address the fundamental performance challenges facing flash-based or flash-integrated storage systems for Internet-scale applications. In this project, we have qualitatively and quantitatively identified the critical issues for existing flash-memory SSDs. We exploited the block liveness information to efficiently supplement the log-block pool with free blocks, and reduce the FTL block mapping table size. Within the framework, we have developed a set of new approaches that can effectively exploit file-system and application semantic knowledge to boost the performance of flash-memory SSDs. The research results have led to the papers published in premier venues (e.g., FAST, USENIX ATC, SC, ICS, HPDC, ICDCS, IPDPS, MSST, MASCOTS, IEEE-TC, IEEE-TPDS, ACM-TOS, etc.), as well as open-source software (SSDSim). We have demonstrated the effectiveness of these approaches using representative benchmarks and real-world applications. Our Turbo Button framework can significantly improve the performance and endurance of non-volatile storage devices in different scale real-world applications across smartphones to cloud environments.

The project provided a very helpful research opportunity in training of three postdoctoral researchers, ten graduate students, and four undergraduate students (including one female graduate student and one female undergraduate student). They have been involved in the design, development, and evaluation of techniques and software, and the research paper writing. The topics related to this research have been developed and incorporated in five senior/graduate level courses at UNL: Computer Architecture, File and Storage Systems, Advanced Computer Architecture, Computer Engineering Professional Development, and Computer Engineering Senior Design Project.
